Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling-Based Design of Freeze-Cast Hybrid Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The freeze-casting process is one with which bulk materials and entire components of several cubic centimeters in size can be manufactured with ease. The process is based on the solidification of water-based solutions or slurries (suspensions). To freeze-cast a scaffold, a solution or slurry is poured into a mold and then directionally solidified. During freezing, the water solidifies in the form of pure ice crystals, and the polymer that was dissolved and the particles that were suspended in this liquid carrier are concentrated between them. Once frozen, the sample is freeze-dried to sublime the ice-phase and reveal the material scaffold; its architecture is the negative of the ice crystals which templated it. The cell wall material structure is the result of a self-assembly process. Freeze casting or "ice templating" is a relatively inexpensive procedure and provides a means to mimic complex, efficient natural materials with hierarchical designs over several length-scales. This award supports research to build models, basic design principles and tools that will enable a systematic approach for the design and manufacture of freeze-cast hybrid materials with enhanced performance. These new materials will be of benefit to both individuals and the general public at large through applications that range from energy generation and storage to tissue repair and regeneration.

This research program focuses on the fundamental science and modeling-driven design of freeze-cast hybrid materials. An interdisciplinary team with expertise in modeling, experiment and characterization will address current knowledge gaps and analyze the formation and evolution of the ice phase and ice-templated material architectures generated by the freeze casting process in an attempt to uncover basic physicochemical principles and determine fundamental processing-structure-property correlations. The three research goals are to (1) determine the underlying fundamental materials science and establish a realistic model for ice-crystal nucleation and growth on a well-defined substrate (graphene) during freeze casting; (2) uncover processing-structure-property correlations by combining multiscale computational modeling with experimental approaches; and (3) develop predictive models to identify the most promising processing-additive combinations in order to custom-design and optimize structure formation and performance in the model material system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project is focused on understanding what controls ice nucleation at the molecular level. It is a key question for developing a science-based design and manufacture of new and improved structural and functional materials using the freeze casting process.

The project has resulted in a few important understandings on ice nucleation mechanisms: First, it demonstrates heterogeneous ice nucleation is controlled by the interplay among surface chemistry, surface chemistry, and surface topography, thus explaining why it is unlikely a single descriptor exists for predicting ice nucleation efficiency. Second, the study presents the first compelling evidence of defect-mediated ice nucleation mechanism, which challenges the traditional wisdom that a good ice nucleator must be capable of inducing water ordering coherent to ice lattice. Third, the study gains new insight into the role of confinement on ice nucleation, which also led to the discovery of the anomalous stability of interfacial ice. The gained mechanisms may also enable new design strategy for controlling ice formation via patterning substrates.

The project has yielded four published journal papers including one Nature Communications paper and one ACS Nano paper, 16 invited talks including two GRC talks and two ACS National Meeting talks.

 

Broader Impact: A fundamental understanding of ice formation enables the development of efficient pro-icing and anti-icing strategies, which bears significance in both science and technology, with far reaching impact in climate modeling, cryopreservation, and defense. Indeed, one of the long-standing questions is what makes an efficient ice nucleator. In addressing this challenging question, this project has yielded some key understandings that enable major advance in   

Although ice nucleation is the process of focus in this project, a large body of the gained understanding extends far beyond ice itself. In particular, the discoveries of topography-enhanced crystallization, defect-mediated nucleation, interfacial ordering, and soft-phonon induced surface instability, find their general significance in the synthesis of a wide range of materials.  

To disseminate research into general public, the PI has been participating Science Olympiad, which is a nation-wide, school-based, and extra-curricular science program that embraces the STEM education for students from third grade through high school. Specifically, the PI has been working closely with Virginia Science Olympiad (VASO) that leads the program at the state (Virginia) level that involves over 2000 K-12 students. In 2017 and 2018, the PI organized the Materials Science event, one of the tournament events of VASO, by composing all the written and lab test materials for both regional and state tournaments and supervising regional tournaments in local high schools. In addition, the PI has also participated the Protein Modeling Event in 2015, 2016 and 2019.  

The project supported four graduate students of which two are female. The project has also led to the first prize ($5,000) for theoretical research in 2018 GWU SEAS R&D Showcase for graduate students.
